title: Isaiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 11.

questions.question: From whose stem shall a rod come forth according to Isaiah 11:1?
options: Jesse
David
Abraham
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Jesse
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:1 states that a rod shall come forth out of the stem of Jesse.

questions.question: Which spirit shall rest upon the Branch as described in Isaiah 11:2?
options: The spirit of the LORD
The spirit of Elijah
The spirit of Moses
The spirit of Gabriel
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:2 mentions that the spirit of the LORD shall rest upon him.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:3, how will he judge?
options: Not by the sight of his eyes nor the hearing of his ears
By the sight of his eyes only
By the hearing of his ears only
By the opinions of others
questions.correctAnswer: Not by the sight of his eyes nor the hearing of his ears
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:3 explains he shall not judge after the sight of his eyes, nor reprove after the hearing of his ears.

questions.question: What will be the girdle of his loins according to Isaiah 11:5?
options: Righteousness
Strength
Mercy
Peace
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:5 states that righteousness shall be the girdle of his loins.

questions.question: Which animals are described as dwelling together in peace in Isaiah 11:6?
options: Wolf and lamb
Lion and eagle
Bear and serpent
Horse and goat
questions.correctAnswer: Wolf and lamb
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6 says the wolf shall dwell with the lamb.

questions.question: Who shall lead the animals as described in Isaiah 11:6?
options: A little child
A prophet
A king
An angel
questions.correctAnswer: A little child
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6 says a little child shall lead them.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:7, what will the lion eat like?
options: Straw like the ox
Meat like a wolf
Fish like a bird
Grass like the lamb
questions.correctAnswer: Straw like the ox
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:7 describes the lion eating straw like the ox.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 11:9 states that they shall hurt and destroy in all the holy mountain.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:9 says they shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain.

questions.question: What will the earth be full of according to Isaiah 11:9?
options: Knowledge of the LORD
Righteousness and justice
Gold and silver
Peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Knowledge of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:9 states the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the LORD.

questions.question: Who shall seek the root of Jesse according to Isaiah 11:10?
options: The Gentiles
The Israelites
The priests
The kings
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:10 says the Gentiles shall seek the root of Jesse.

questions.question: From which places will the Lord recover the remnant of his people as listed in Isaiah 11:11?
options: Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, islands of the sea
Babylon, Persia, Media, Egypt
Rome, Greece, Egypt, Assyria
Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Nazareth
questions.correctAnswer: Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, islands of the sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:11 lists these specific places from which the Lord will recover the remnant of his people.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 11:13 says that Ephraim will envy Judah and Judah will vex Ephraim.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:13 states the envy of Ephraim shall depart and Judah shall not vex Ephraim.

questions.question: What will the LORD destroy according to Isaiah 11:15?
options: The tongue of the Egyptian sea
The walls of Jerusalem
The idols of the nations
The mountains of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: The tongue of the Egyptian sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:15 states the LORD shall utterly destroy the tongue of the Egyptian sea.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 11:16 talks about a highway for the remnant of his people from Assyria.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:16 describes a highway for the remnant of his people from Assyria.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 11:4: 'And with the breath of his lips shall he ______ the wicked.'
options: slay
bless
save
teach
questions.correctAnswer: slay
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:4 says he shall slay the wicked with the breath of his lips.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by unfair treatment at work and seeks guidance on judging fairly. Based on Isaiah 11, what biblical truth would you share about righteous judgment?
options: Judge with righteousness and equity, not by appearances or hearsay
Judge quickly to avoid prolonged disputes
Judge only those close to you with mercy
Judge based on popular opinion
questions.correctAnswer: Judge with righteousness and equity, not by appearances or hearsay
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:3-4 teaches that judgment should not be based on what is seen or heard superficially, but with righteousness and equity, especially defending the poor and meek. This establishes a model for fair and just behavior in daily life.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11 describe the qualities the Spirit of the LORD imparts that can guide a believer in living with wisdom and integrity?
options: Spirit of wisdom, understanding, counsel, might, knowledge, and fear of the LORD
Spirit of power, fame, riches, and honor
Spirit of joy, peace, love, and patience
Spirit of prophecy, tongues, miracles, and healing
questions.correctAnswer: Spirit of wisdom, understanding, counsel, might, knowledge, and fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:2 outlines these specific spiritual gifts from the LORD that equip a believer for wise and faithful living, emphasizing reverence for God as foundational.

questions.question: A believer struggling with anxiety asks about trusting God's protection. According to Isaiah 11, what imagery illustrates God's peace and safety?
options: The wolf shall dwell with the lamb, and a little child shall lead them
The eagle shall soar above the mountains
The river shall never dry up
The sun shall shine without setting
questions.correctAnswer: The wolf shall dwell with the lamb, and a little child shall lead them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6 uses peaceful coexistence of natural enemies and the innocence of a child leading them to symbolize God's peace and protection over His creation, encouraging trust and calm.

questions.question: In dealing with temptation, what does Isaiah 11 teach about the power of God's word and authority over evil?
options: He shall smite the earth with the rod of his mouth and slay the wicked with the breath of his lips
He shall fight physically against evil
He shall pray silently without confrontation
He shall ignore evil and focus on good
questions.correctAnswer: He shall smite the earth with the rod of his mouth and slay the wicked with the breath of his lips
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:4 shows the power of God's spoken word as authoritative and effective against wickedness, encouraging believers to rely on God's word in confronting temptation and evil.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11 encourage humility and faithfulness in the life of a believer?
options: Righteousness shall be the girdle of his loins, and faithfulness the girdle of his reins
Wealth and power will be signs of God's favor
Popularity and influence will prove faithfulness
Success in all things is guaranteed
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness shall be the girdle of his loins, and faithfulness the girdle of his reins
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:5 highlights righteousness and faithfulness as essential virtues that should 'gird' or support a believer's life, teaching the importance of integrity and steadfastness.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 11 teaches that God's knowledge will fill the earth like the waters cover the sea, bringing peace and safety.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:9 explicitly states that the earth will be full of the knowledge of the LORD as the waters cover the sea, which is linked to peace and the absence of harm.

questions.question: What biblical truth about reconciliation between believers does Isaiah 11 teach through the example of Ephraim and Judah?
options: Envy and adversaries shall depart; they shall not vex or envy each other
They shall remain in constant conflict
One shall dominate the other
They shall ignore each other
questions.correctAnswer: Envy and adversaries shall depart; they shall not vex or envy each other
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:13 teaches that envy and hostility between Ephraim and Judah will cease, illustrating how God desires peace and unity among His people.

questions.question: A believer is called to evangelism and outreach. According to Isaiah 11, what future hope encourages sharing the Gospel with Gentiles?
options: The root of Jesse shall stand as an ensign to which the Gentiles shall seek
Only Israelites will be saved
Gentiles will be excluded from God's promises
The Gospel is only for the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: The root of Jesse shall stand as an ensign to which the Gentiles shall seek
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:10 speaks of a root from Jesse (Messiah) who will be a banner for the peoples, drawing Gentiles to God, encouraging believers to evangelize all nations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11 encourage perseverance through trials when God promises to recover His people from many places?
options: The LORD will recover the remnant of His people from many lands, showing His faithfulness
Believers will be abandoned during hardship
Only those in Jerusalem will be saved
Salvation depends on human effort alone
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will recover the remnant of His people from many lands, showing His faithfulness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:11-12 assures believers of God's active hand in restoring His people from distant places, encouraging trust in His faithful deliverance amid trials.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 11 teach about the role of a child in God's peaceful kingdom, and how might this inform Christian parenting?
options: A little child shall lead the animals in peace, showing the value of innocence and guidance
Children will be excluded from leadership
Only strong warriors lead the kingdom
Children must earn their place through strength
questions.correctAnswer: A little child shall lead the animals in peace, showing the value of innocence and guidance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6 illustrates a child leading predators and prey in harmony, symbolizing humility, innocence, and trust—qualities parents are encouraged to nurture.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 11, God's kingdom is marked by the cessation of harm and destruction among all creatures.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:9 states that in God's holy mountain, nothing will hurt or destroy, emphasizing a kingdom characterized by peace and safety.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11 inspire integrity and honesty in a believer's daily work life?
options: Faithfulness and righteousness gird the loins and reins, urging integrity in all actions
Success justifies any means
Deceit is acceptable if it benefits the community
Work is unimportant in spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness and righteousness gird the loins and reins, urging integrity in all actions
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:5 uses the metaphor of righteousness and faithfulness as girdles supporting a person, implying that believers should maintain honesty and integrity in all they do.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive an adversary. What encouragement from Isaiah 11 could you share about God’s plan for reconciliation?
options: Envy and adversaries will be removed, and there will be no vexation between tribes
Adversaries must be defeated by force
Forgiveness is optional
Adversaries will always remain
questions.correctAnswer: Envy and adversaries will be removed, and there will be no vexation between tribes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:13 promises that envy and hostility will depart and that groups will cease to vex one another, encouraging believers to pursue forgiveness and peace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 11:16, there shall be an __________ for the remnant of God's people, similar to when Israel came out of Egypt.
options: highway
altar
mountain
river
questions.correctAnswer: highway
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:16 describes a highway prepared for the remnant of God's people, symbolizing a clear, safe path for restoration and deliverance as in the Exodus.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11 describe God's power over natural obstacles to encourage believers facing difficult circumstances?
options: The LORD shakes His hand over rivers, making them passable dryshod
God lets obstacles remain to test believers
Natural obstacles will never be removed
Believers must remove obstacles by their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shakes His hand over rivers, making them passable dryshod
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:15 shows God's mighty power to remove natural barriers, encouraging believers to trust in His ability to make a way through difficulties.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 11.

questions.question: What symbolic figure in Isaiah 11:1 is used to represent the coming leader from Jesse's lineage, and what is its typological significance in Christian theology?
options: Rod and Branch; a Messianic prophecy pointing to Jesus as the Davidic king
Lion and Lamb; symbolizing peace in the Messianic age
Scepter and Crown; indicating royal authority over Israel
Sword and Shield; representing divine protection in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Rod and Branch; a Messianic prophecy pointing to Jesus as the Davidic king
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:1 speaks of a 'rod... out of the stem of Jesse' and a 'Branch' from his roots, typologically understood as a Messianic prophecy pointing to Jesus, a descendant of David (Jesse's son), who brings salvation and kingship.

questions.question: Which six attributes of the Spirit of the LORD are enumerated upon the prophesied ruler in Isaiah 11:2, and how do they reflect ancient Hebrew wisdom literature?
options: Wisdom, Understanding, Counsel, Might, Knowledge, Fear of the LORD
Strength, Honor, Courage, Patience, Faith, Hope
Mercy, Justice, Peace, Joy, Truth, Righteousness
Love, Compassion, Humility, Obedience, Prayer, Praise
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom, Understanding, Counsel, Might, Knowledge, Fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:2 lists these six attributes, echoing themes from Proverbs and other wisdom texts that emphasize the Spirit's role in guiding just and wise leadership.

questions.question: In Isaiah 11:3, what judicial principle is emphasized about the coming leader's decision-making, and how does this contrast with common human judgment?
options: Judges not by sight or hearing but with reverence for God
Judges strictly by the law without mercy
Judges according to the majority opinion
Judges based on wealth and social status
questions.correctAnswer: Judges not by sight or hearing but with reverence for God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:3 highlights that the leader will not judge superficially by appearances or hearsay but will act with deep reverence for the LORD, ensuring righteous and fair decisions.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11:4 depict the means by which the prophesied leader executes justice and punishes the wicked, and what literary device is used here?
options: By the rod of his mouth and breath of his lips; metaphor illustrating the power of his word
By sword and shield; literal weapons of war
By judgment and prison; judicial punishment
By exile and famine; divine curses
questions.correctAnswer: By the rod of his mouth and breath of his lips; metaphor illustrating the power of his word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:4 uses metaphorical language to show the leader's authority through speech—his word is as powerful as a rod or breath to enact justice and destroy the wicked.

questions.question: What do the imagery of animals dwelling together peacefully in Isaiah 11:6-9 symbolize in the context of ancient Near Eastern expectations of the Messianic age?
options: A radical peace and restoration of creation under God's reign
An allegory for Israel's conquest of neighboring nations
A description of Eden's original animal order
A warning about the dangers of wild beasts
questions.correctAnswer: A radical peace and restoration of creation under God's reign
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6-9 uses peaceful coexistence of natural enemies as a symbolic vision of cosmic peace and restoration expected during the Messianic kingdom, a common theme in ancient Near Eastern prophetic literature.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:10, what role will the 'root of Jesse' play for the Gentiles, and how does this reflect the book's universalistic hope?
options: An ensign for the people; Gentiles will seek him for guidance and rest
A war leader; Gentiles will be conquered by him
A judge; Gentiles will be excluded from his rule
A priest; Gentiles will bring offerings to him
questions.correctAnswer: An ensign for the people; Gentiles will seek him for guidance and rest
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:10 portrays the 'root of Jesse' as a banner or sign for all peoples, including Gentiles, symbolizing the expansion of God's salvation beyond Israel to all nations.

questions.question: The phrase 'the Lord shall set his hand again the second time' in Isaiah 11:11 suggests what about God's intervention in history, and how does it relate to prior redemptive acts?
options: A renewed act of deliverance following the Exodus
The first creation of Israel as a nation
The destruction of Israel for disobedience
The establishment of the Temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: A renewed act of deliverance following the Exodus
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:11 alludes to a second divine intervention, paralleling God's initial redeeming act in the Exodus, now aimed at regathering the remnant of Israel from exile.

questions.question: Which geographical regions are mentioned in Isaiah 11:11 as places from which the remnant of Israel will be gathered, reflecting the historical dispersion of the people?
options: Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, Islands of the sea
Babylon, Persia, Media, Greece, Rome, Egypt, Canaan, Edom
Philistia, Moab, Ammon, Edom, Syria, Lebanon, Arabia, Egypt
Jerusalem, Samaria, Bethlehem, Nazareth, Hebron, Jericho, Galilee, Judea
questions.correctAnswer: Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, Islands of the sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:11 lists these ancient Near Eastern regions from which the Israelites were dispersed, indicating the comprehensive regathering God will effect.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'envy of Ephraim' departing as described in Isaiah 11:13, particularly in the context of Israelite tribal relations?
options: It signifies reconciliation between the northern and southern tribes
It predicts the conquest of Ephraim by Judah
It refers to the destruction of Ephraim by foreign nations
It symbolizes the division of Israel into two kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies reconciliation between the northern and southern tribes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:13 indicates the end of hostility and jealousy between Ephraim (Northern Kingdom) and Judah (Southern Kingdom), symbolizing future unity among God's people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 11:14 describe the military actions of Israel against the Philistines, Edom, Moab, and Ammon, and what does this imply about Israel's restored power?
options: They will fly upon the shoulders of the Philistines and lay hands upon Edom and Moab; showing renewed dominance
They will seek peace treaties with these nations; indicating diplomacy
They will be defeated by these nations; reflecting Israel's weakness
They will ignore these nations; focusing only on internal affairs
questions.correctAnswer: They will fly upon the shoulders of the Philistines and lay hands upon Edom and Moab; showing renewed dominance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:14 depicts Israel's military ascendancy over neighboring peoples, symbolizing God's restoration of Israel's national strength and influence.

questions.question: What natural phenomena are described in Isaiah 11:15 to illustrate God's power over Egypt, and what historical event might this allude to?
options: The destruction of the Egyptian sea and dry passage over the river; alluding to the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
A great flood covering Egypt; referencing Noah's flood
A plague of locusts; symbolizing divine judgment
A volcanic eruption; describing a natural disaster
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of the Egyptian sea and dry passage over the river; alluding to the Exodus crossing of the Red Sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:15 recalls God's mighty acts in the Exodus when He parted the Red Sea, illustrating His sovereignty and ability to save His people.

questions.question: In Isaiah 11:16, what is the 'highway' for the remnant of God's people, and how does it connect to Israel's historical journey?
options: A secure path from Assyria like the Exodus route from Egypt
A new trade route built by Israel’s enemies
A metaphor for economic prosperity
The road to exile in Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: A secure path from Assyria like the Exodus route from Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:16 metaphorically describes a safe passage for the returning remnant, paralleling the historical path God provided during the Exodus from Egypt.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 11:5 describes righteousness and faithfulness as elements that metaphorically secure the leader's strength and integrity, similar to a girdle around the loins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:5 uses the metaphor of a girdle to portray righteousness and faithfulness as the leader's strength and moral integrity.

questions.question: What is the role of the 'little child' in Isaiah 11:6-8 in the peaceful coexistence of predatory and prey animals, and what theological theme does this illustrate?
options: The child leads and harmonizes nature; illustrating the restoration of innocence and divine peace
The child is prey for the animals; illustrating human vulnerability
The child hides from danger; illustrating fear in a hostile world
The child teaches animals to fight; symbolizing human dominion
questions.correctAnswer: The child leads and harmonizes nature; illustrating the restoration of innocence and divine peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6-8 depicts a child leading predators and prey in harmony, symbolizing the Messianic peace and restoration of God's original creation order.

questions.question: How does the prophecy in Isaiah 11:12 about assembling the outcasts of Israel from the four corners of the earth connect with New Testament themes of the inclusion of Gentiles?
options: It foreshadows the gathering of a unified people of God including Gentiles, as seen in Acts and Paul’s epistles
It predicts the destruction of Israel without hope of restoration
It refers exclusively to a political reunification of Israelite tribes
It contradicts New Testament teachings on Gentile inclusion
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the gathering of a unified people of God including Gentiles, as seen in Acts and Paul’s epistles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:12’s vision of regathering Israel from all corners prefigures the New Testament theme of the Church as a unified body of Jew and Gentile believers.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:1, from whose stem shall a rod come forth, symbolizing the Messiah's lineage?
options: Jesse
David
Abraham
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Jesse
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:1 states that a rod will come forth out of the stem of Jesse, indicating the Messiah's Davidic lineage. This is consistent with Matthew 1:6 and Romans 15:12, which affirm Jesus as a descendant of Jesse through David.

questions.question: What sixfold spirit rests upon the Messiah as described in Isaiah 11:2?
options: Wisdom, Understanding, Counsel, Might, Knowledge, Fear of the LORD
Love, Joy, Peace, Patience, Kindness, Goodness
Faith, Hope, Charity, Temperance, Fortitude, Justice
Power, Glory, Majesty, Holiness, Truth, Righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom, Understanding, Counsel, Might, Knowledge, Fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:2 lists these six spirits upon the Messiah, highlighting the Holy Spirit's manifold work. This aligns with Proverbs 2:6, John 14:26, and 1 Corinthians 12:4-11 which speak of the Spirit's gifts and attributes.

questions.question: How will the Messiah judge according to Isaiah 11:3?
options: Not by what he sees or hears but with reverence for the LORD
By the law and the prophets
Through popular opinion
By the strength of his own will
questions.correctAnswer: Not by what he sees or hears but with reverence for the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:3 emphasizes that the Messiah will judge not by outward appearances but with the fear of the LORD, reflecting divine wisdom. This parallels John 5:30 and John 7:24 regarding Christ's righteous judgment.

questions.question: What is the Messiah's method of punishing the wicked as described in Isaiah 11:4?
options: With the rod of his mouth and breath of his lips
By fire and brimstone
By the sword of angels
Through earthly kings
questions.correctAnswer: With the rod of his mouth and breath of his lips
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:4 describes the Messiah's authority exercised through His word, symbolized by the rod of his mouth and the breath of his lips. Hebrews 1:3 and Revelation 19:15 echo this theme of Christ's powerful spoken judgment.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:5, which two qualities are described as the girdle of the Messiah's loins and reins?
options: Righteousness and Faithfulness
Mercy and Justice
Power and Glory
Love and Peace
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness and Faithfulness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:5 states that righteousness and faithfulness gird the Messiah, indicating His moral perfection and reliability. This is consistent with Psalm 89:14 and 2 Timothy 2:13 which describe God's righteousness and faithfulness.

questions.question: Which peaceful coexistence imagery is used in Isaiah 11:6 to illustrate the Messiah's reign?
options: Wolf with the lamb, leopard with the kid, calf with the lion
Lion with the lamb, eagle with the dove, serpent with the dove
Bear with the ox, eagle with the lion, wolf with the goat
Serpent with the lamb, lion with the calf, wolf with the kid
questions.correctAnswer: Wolf with the lamb, leopard with the kid, calf with the lion
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:6 portrays a harmonious new creation where natural enemies dwell peacefully, symbolizing the Messiah's transformative reign. This aligns with Romans 8:19-22 and Revelation 21:4 describing restoration of creation.

questions.question: In Isaiah 11:8, what is the significance of a child playing near the hole of the asp and putting his hand on the cockatrice' den?
options: It symbolizes complete peace and safety under the Messiah's kingdom
It warns of danger despite peace
It illustrates the Messiah's childhood
It depicts the power of evil
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes complete peace and safety under the Messiah's kingdom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:8 depicts a world so transformed that even the most vulnerable are safe from harm, symbolizing the eschatological peace Christ brings. This is echoed in Psalm 91:13 and Romans 5:1 about peace and protection.

questions.question: What will fill the earth according to Isaiah 11:9?
options: The knowledge of the LORD
The fear of man
The worship of idols
The power of kings
questions.correctAnswer: The knowledge of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:9 promises a time when the earth will be full of the knowledge of the LORD, a fundamental theme in biblical eschatology. Habakkuk 2:14 and Jeremiah 31:34 affirm the universal knowledge of God in the future.

questions.question: Who will seek the root of Jesse as an ensign of the people in Isaiah 11:10?
options: Gentiles
Only Israel
Angels
Kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:10 states that Gentiles will seek the root of Jesse, indicating the Messiah's role in salvation extending beyond Israel. This is consistent with Romans 15:12 and Acts 10:34-35 about Gentile inclusion.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:11, from which regions will the Lord recover the remnant of His people?
options: Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, Islands of the sea
Babylon, Persia, Greece, Rome
Canaan, Moab, Edom, Ammon
Edom, Philistia, Syria, Lebanon
questions.correctAnswer: Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, Islands of the sea
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:11 lists these specific regions from where God will gather His people, highlighting His sovereign restoration plan. This corresponds with Ezekiel 37:21-22 and Jeremiah 23:3 about regathering Israel.

questions.question: What will the Lord set up for the nations according to Isaiah 11:12?
options: An ensign to assemble the outcasts of Israel
A new temple in Jerusalem
A mighty army to conquer
A law to govern all peoples
questions.correctAnswer: An ensign to assemble the outcasts of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:12 describes God raising a banner to gather the dispersed of Judah and Israel, symbolizing salvation and unity. This is reflected in Isaiah 49:22-23 and John 12:32 where Christ draws all people to Himself.

questions.question: What will happen to the envy between Ephraim and Judah as prophesied in Isaiah 11:13?
options: The envy will depart, and adversaries will be cut off
The envy will increase, causing division
They will merge into one tribe immediately
They will battle until the end of days
questions.correctAnswer: The envy will depart, and adversaries will be cut off
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:13 foretells the end of rivalry between Ephraim and Judah, indicating restored unity, consistent with Ezekiel 37:15-22 and Galatians 3:28 about reconciliation in Christ.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 11:14, upon whose shoulders will they fly, and which peoples will they spoil?
options: Philistines; Edom and Moab; children of Ammon
Babylonians; Assyrians and Egyptians; Canaanites
Romans; Greeks and Persians; Philistines
Edomites; Moabites and Ammonites; Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines; Edom and Moab; children of Ammon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:14 describes the restored people flying upon the Philistines' shoulders and spoiling Edom, Moab, and Ammon. This conveys divine victory and dominion, paralleling Numbers 24:24 and Psalm 108:9.

questions.question: What will the LORD do to the Egyptian sea according to Isaiah 11:15?
options: Utterly destroy the tongue of the sea and make men go over dryshod
Part the sea to save His people
Turn the sea into blood as judgment
Calm the sea to bring peace
questions.correctAnswer: Utterly destroy the tongue of the sea and make men go over dryshod
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:15 prophesies God's judgment over Egypt, making a path dry across the river, reminiscent of Exodus 14:21-22 and Psalm 77:16-20 where God parts waters for deliverance.

questions.question: What will be made for the remnant of God's people from Assyria according to Isaiah 11:16?
options: An highway like the one from Egypt
A new temple in Jerusalem
A mighty fortress for protection
A river of living water
questions.correctAnswer: An highway like the one from Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 11:16 promises a highway for the remnant like the way God led Israel out of Egypt, signifying divine guidance and restoration. This theme is echoed in Isaiah 35:8 and Hebrews 11:29 about God's providential leading.
